awd_titl_txt: QRM: Hybrid Adversarial-Training Methods for 3D Virtual Microstructures
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support research that will develop a rigorous scientific method in quantifying the internal structure, or microstructure, of engineering materials, advancing the frontiers of science and benefiting the US economy. Microstructure determines the properties and performance of engineering materials, but is often described in qualitative rather than quantitative terms. This award supports fundamental research to build the scientific tools to quantify microstructure, and enable the creation of digital representations of microstructure that can be used for computational simulations to predict material performance in structural and functional applications. This project uses state-of-the-art data science and machine-learning (ML), to build quantitatively accurate, high-fidelity virtual microstructures, and combines these tools with physics-based computational models to predict how materials in service respond to extreme environments. The resulting capabilities allow for the design of high-performance materials for manufacturing, infrastructure, and aerospace, and have the potential to transform how materials are brought from the laboratory to commercial applications.

This project uses state-of-the-art data science and machine-learning to build virtual microstructures with bounded uncertainty.  The approach builds upon "shape-optimizers" existing within the DREAM.3D synthetic microstructure software, and the nascent capabilities of generative adversarial networks (GAN).  These methods will be statistically coupled to experimental data for gains in quantitative representation accuracy.  The virtual microstructures represented in phase-field simulations will serve as one quality metric for the ML prediction.  The hybrid method explores and exploits use of the GAN methods to offset weaknesses within shape-optimizer and phase-transformation methods.  The goal is to obtain complete, realistic, and accurate virtual structures.  To demonstrate the gains from the new hybrid method, uncertainty quantification (UQ) techniques will be concurrently developed using both virtual "materials phantoms," and evaluations of material descriptors from both synthetic structures and experiments.  The effort builds from open-source software and public datasets in the Materials Engineering and Machine Learning fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The internal structure or microstructure of materials is the defining concept for the field of materials science and engineering. The properties and performance of engineering materials is directly dependent on this microstructure. Additionally, this microstructure evolves during processing, such as heating, deformation, and quenching leading to a change in material properties. Given the importance of microstructure it is critical to have an accurate computer representation of microstructure for use in scientific, engineering, and design computational models and simulations. This project focused on using novel machine learning tools to create high fidelity digital or virtual models of material structure inside the computer that can be used as input to physics-based materials simulations.

The machine learning tools should be able to create many realizations of a structure. Two oak trees in a forest will share many common features. These common features allow us to identify them as oaks. However, each tree will have differences that are partially shaped by the environment and partially random. The internal structure of materials is the same as well. Two samples of a metal such as 316 stainless steel will have many features at the microscopic scale which are shared between them, but each sample will look distinct under a microscope. The spatial arrangement of features will be slightly different. These differences are functions of the processing but also contain an element of randomness. The machine tools should be able to generate many different digital steel samples, each of which are unique but also share all of necessary features.

In this project we developed two different machine learning approaches. 1) Physics Based Regularization for Generative Adversarial Networks (PBGAN) and 2) Advanced Hierarchical Variational Autoencoders (AHVAE). The key features of these network are that they utilize adversarial training. Under the cover they are actually two machine learning models. The first is the generator, the network that learns to create the digital image. The second is the discriminator, or a critic that tries to differentiate the output from the generator from real training data. By training these networks together and against each other, the system learns much faster than a generator trained by itself.

The first approach PBGAN, utilizes physical laws we already know to help the network learn faster and more completely. Most ML tools learn only from the data. The networks are fed lots of data and the ML tool looks for correlation and structure to learn. However, we showed that by incorporating some prior knowledge in the form of physical laws into the network it took much less training data for the network to learn these correlations. For example, if you were training a network to make pictures of rainbows a network that was programed with prior knowledge of ROYGBIV would probably be able to learn how to do it faster than one that had to learn to observe that spectrum. In our case, we showed that we could train a ML model to predict the mechanical response of a composite better and faster if the network started off by knowing the fundamental laws of stress equilibrium and conservation of linear and angular momentum.

The second approach AHVAE utilized a novel structure to capture multiple length scales in the microscopy data. Imagine a network that was trying to learn to layout cities. You could train in on large scale aerial photos but it wouldn't learn the structure of individual buildings that way. You could also train in on pictures of building but it wouldn't learn how cites are laid out in blocks and neighborhoods. The AHVAE utilizes a special representation that internally looks at the microstructure and builds a representation that contains both short- and long-range data.

From a Materials Science and Education perspective, the effort expanded the working familiarity and impact of ML tools within MSE, while at the same time enabling MSE practitioners to give feedback to the ML community about aspects of the tools and improvements. In so doing, this research enhanced student software, coding, and ML skills, that are the most sought STEM skills. This project also directly involved high school students from the METRO Early Career High School in the research.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/16/2023
Modified by: Stephen R Niezgoda

    Steve Niezgoda

    AHVAE Applications
  • The hierarchical nature of the Adversarial Hierarchical Variational Autoencoder allows for the multiscale nature of material structure to be appropriately captured and defined.
    Steve Niezgoda
